questions.text: The patient complains of intermittent claudication, dizziness, headache and cyanosis localised to the lower half of the body. The most likely cause is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Coarctation of the aorta COA presents with intermittent claudication due to a decrease in blood supply in the major vessel of an upper limb due to coarctation just before the branching, mostly seen before the branching of the subclavian vessel.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A . TOF presents with cyanotic spells also called TET spells Option: B . ASD is usually asymptomatic. The most important auscultatory finding is wide Fixed S2 Option: D . PDA presents with a machinery murmur on auscultation.

questions.text: A 10-year child on general examination shows radio-femoral delay. A suspicion of coarctation of the aorta is made. Which is the investigation of choice?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

MRI Imaging by MRI is the investigation of choice.

Highyeild:

Fig. 16.93 MRI scan of coarctation of the aorta. The aorta is severely narrowed just beyond the arch at the start of the descending aorta (arrow A). Extensive collaterals have developed; a large internal mammary artery (arrow B) and several intercostal arteries (arrows C) are shown. Unusually, in this case, there is also a coarctation of the abdominal aorta (arrow D). B

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Left ventricular hypertrophy, which can be confirmed by echocardiography. Option: B. The chest X-ray in early childhood is often normal but later may show changes in the contour of the aorta (indentation of the descending aorta, ‘3 sign’) and notching of the under-surfaces of the ribs from collaterals. Option: D. The ECG may show evidence of left ventricular hypertrophy, which can be confirmed by echocardiography.

questions.text: A neonate presents to the pediatric clinic with cyanosis localised to the lower half of the body. The child couldn't survive and post-mortem studies pointed out the presence of tubular hypoplasia of the aortic arch, proximal to PDA accompanied by a bicuspid aortic valve. What could be the possible diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Coarctation of the aorta Keywords for diagnosis - Neonate with Cyanosis - the lower half Tubular hypoplasia proximal to PDA Bicuspid aortic valve With the given history, we can confirm our diagnosis as COA.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A . sub Valvular aortic stenosis is caused by thickened ring or collar of dense endocardial fibrous tissue below the level of cusps. This does not present with the given features, except that it is congenital and related to the Option: B . pulmonary stenosis- obstruction at the level of the pulmonary valve. Can be isolated or developed as a part of TOF. It is an anomaly of the pulmonary artery. Option: D . Transposition of great arteries present with cyanosis at birth and it lacks the differentially localised cyanosis , hence eliminated.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man visited his family doctor because he had a cough. A chest radiograph demonstrated a notch at the inferior border of the ribs. He was referred to a cardiologist and a diagnosis of coarctation of the aorta was made. Which among the following vessels is NOT responsible for the development of the given radiographic findings?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1st and 2nd posterior intercostal arteries The 1st and 2nd posterior intercostal vessels are supplied from the costocervical trunk, which arises from the subclavian artery proximal to the coarctation, so do not induce rib notching .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. - The given clinical stem mentioned the diagnosis of coarctation of the aorta and The radiographic finding shows a characteristic rib notching Pattern. It develops along the inferior border of ribs from the 3rd to the 6th. Commonly internal thoracic, superior epigastric, and musculophrenic arteries enlarge anteriorly. Options: C and D. - They supply anterior intercostal arteries, which join the posterior intercostal and allow blood to flow back to the distal aorta. Enlargement of these intercostal vessels results in notching of the ribs.

questions.text: A 72-year-old obese woman was referred to our hospital because of increasing fatigue and exertional dyspnea. The patient had a medical history of diabetes, dyslipidemia and poorly controlled hypertension. Physical examination showed blood pressure of 125/75 in both arms and a heart rate of 77 beats/minute. A systolic ejection murmur was heard at the left upper sternal border. Femoral pulses were palpable bilaterally but weak and delayed compared to the brachial pulses. Notching of the ribs was observed on the chest radiography. Which of the following is CORRECT with respect to the given diagnosis? Severe coarctation can be associated with continuous murmur over the scapula. Many Infants suffering from COA associated with PDA don't survive the neonatal period without surgical or catheter-based interventions to occlude the PDA Coarctation of the aorta is the most common congenital cardiovascular cause of hypertension. In infants, It can manifest as a part of TOF or TGA.The right, to left shunt is responsible for introducing poorly oxygenated blood into the systemic circulation. Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Only 1,2,3 are correct Here the diagnosis is clearly coarctation of the aorta distal to the left subclavian artery this narrowing can reduce blood flow to the lower body Statement 1- In severe coarctation, a continuous murmur over the scapula may be present , due to collateral blood flow developed around the chest wall. This is to bypass excess blood collection in the proximal aorta to the distal thoracic aorta via intercostal vessels. Statement 2- COA with PDA manifest early in life and may cause sign and symptoms immediately after birth, in such cases, infants don’t survive without surgical or catheter-based interventions. Statement 3- Coarctation of the aorta is the most common congenital cardiovascular cause of hypertension.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Statement 4- Pulmonary stenosis and atresia: the lesions can be isolated or part of a more complex anomaly - either TGA or TOF Statement 5- right to left shunts are most commonly caused by TOF or TGA. COA is generally not associated with right to left shunt. Whereas It can give rise to left ventricular hypertrophy because of outflow tract obstruction.

questions.text: A child presents to the clinic with weak pulses and claudication. On examination, there is hypertension in the upper extremities and hypotension in the lower extremities. After investigations, the patient was diagnosed with COA without PDA. Which of the following will occur in this patient because of the development of collateral circulation between pre-coarctation and post-coarctation arteries? Visible erosions on the undersurface of ribs Murmurs throughout systole and a vibratory thrill Dilatation of a pulmonary artery Inverted 3 sign on barium swallow Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Only 1 and 2 are correct Diagnosis of COA is given in the question. Enlargement of these intercostal vessels results in notching of the ribs . And when blood passes through these vessels under pressure (which happens during systole), the turbulent flow gives rise to murmur throughout systole . As these collaterals are around the chest wall, the murmur if severe can present as a vibratory thrill.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Statement 3- Dilations of the pulmonary artery: it has nothing to do with COA. The pulmonary artery can be dilated most commonly due to pulmonary artery hypertension. Statement 4- The inverted 3 sign (also known as the E sign) is seen on barium swallow in patients with coarctation of the aorta and is the medial equivalent of the figure 3 sign seen on plain chest radiographs. It is formed by pre stenotic dilatation of the ascending aorta, the indentation of the coarctation site (or "tuck"), and post-stenotic dilatation of the descending aorta.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female with short stature, webbed neck, lymphedema and primary amenorrhoea came to OPD. A concomitant diagnosis of Turner's was considered. On examination a continuous murmur over the scapula with blood pressure 140/90 0ver the upper limb and 110/70 over the lower limb. A diagnosis of an obstructive lesion was made based on the given findings by the attending physician. Which among the following can NOT be the possible sequelae of the diagnosed obstructive lesion? 1. Pulmonary hypertension 2. Ascending or descending aortic enlargement or aneurysm 3. Left ventricular hypertrophy 4. Left ventricular diastolic and systolic heart failure 5. Accelerated cerebral and coronary atherosclerosis 6. No recurrence of the defect after surgical repair Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1 and 6 Keywords for diagnosis- Female with Turner’s Significant blood pressure difference between upper and lower limb Obstructive lesion So possible obstructive lesion with a difference between the upper and lower limb - the possibility of coarctation of the aorta .
